snippet.textDisplay: They could do that with earlier NES games because it showed off what the NES could do versus Atari. It was good, honest marketing. It went to show that the NES didn't need games with overly complicated box art to be successful. "Now you're playing with power."

snippet.textDisplay: @Koopsas There's something to be said of the limitations of older game music. They just didn't have the room on the cartridge for full .mp3 files with whatever they wanted; they had to compose with specific programs (trackers) made to store the song in as small a space as possible. I believe that on the NES, 4 layers (including percussion) was the absolute maximum (I may be wrong, though). Nowadays you can get dozens (or more) layers with full orchestras if you want. Not that I'm complaining.
snippet.textOriginal: @Koopsas There's something to be said of the limitations of older game music. They just didn't have the room on the cartridge for full .mp3 files with whatever they wanted; they had to compose with specific programs (trackers) made to store the song in as small a space as possible. I believe that on the NES, 4 layers (including percussion) was the absolute maximum (I may be wrong, though). Nowadays you can get dozens (or more) layers with full orchestras if you want. Not that I'm complaining.

snippet.textDisplay: @MrTanookiMario Oh i get it, the only two notes that overlap are the melody and the bass, and they are only comprised of only 1 note playing at any given time, thus only 2 notes are ever playing throughout the entire song. Wow, that is quite skill full. thanks.
snippet.textOriginal: @MrTanookiMario Oh i get it, the only two notes that overlap are the melody and the bass, and they are only comprised of only 1 note playing at any given time, thus only 2 notes are ever playing throughout the entire song. Wow, that is quite skill full. thanks.

snippet.textDisplay:
@Koopsas
There's only two "layers" of monophonic instruments (they play only one note at a time, like a clarinet or a flute--as opposed to polyphonic instruments like a piano) in the whole song. One plays the melody, and the other does the bass. There's no drums, no complex layers of harmonies or chords or anything--just two notes at any given time.
snippet.textOriginal:
@Koopsas
There's only two "layers" of monophonic instruments (they play only one note at a time, like a clarinet or a flute--as opposed to polyphonic instruments like a piano) in the whole song. One plays the melody, and the other does the bass. There's no drums, no complex layers of harmonies or chords or anything--just two notes at any given time.

snippet.textDisplay:
The attention to detail in this era for the most part was pretty amazing, but there are some modern games that have some memorable music in their own right.  

The music for the cut scenes in Xenosaga II composed by Yuki Kajiura is such an impressive collection of music I was compelled to purchase the soundtrack.

Of course working with a full orchestra helps, but  like games from this era, the atmosphere created forces you to acknowledge the music and not simply listen to it.
snippet.textOriginal:
The attention to detail in this era for the most part was pretty amazing, but there are some modern games that have some memorable music in their own right.  

The music for the cut scenes in Xenosaga II composed by Yuki Kajiura is such an impressive collection of music I was compelled to purchase the soundtrack.

Of course working with a full orchestra helps, but  like games from this era, the atmosphere created forces you to acknowledge the music and not simply listen to it.

snippet.textDisplay:
I agree. the lack of soundchannels made the composers loads more creative. They created themes that are forever stuck in millions upon millions of people's minds. 

Nowadays the music tends to be very backgroundish, you never recall it after you have played through a game really.

in the 8bit and 16bit era, possibly 32/64 too, the music wasa bigger part of the whole experience in general.

Of course, exceptions do exist. ;)
snippet.textOriginal:
I agree. the lack of soundchannels made the composers loads more creative. They created themes that are forever stuck in millions upon millions of people's minds. 

Nowadays the music tends to be very backgroundish, you never recall it after you have played through a game really.

in the 8bit and 16bit era, possibly 32/64 too, the music wasa bigger part of the whole experience in general.

Of course, exceptions do exist. ;)

snippet.textDisplay:
Listen again to this song. For the ENTIRE track, there are only TWO lines of notes playing. Two. That's 2. And it sucks you in and holds you there.

I DARE you to find a song from a modern video game done with that level of skill.
snippet.textOriginal:
Listen again to this song. For the ENTIRE track, there are only TWO lines of notes playing. Two. That's 2. And it sucks you in and holds you there.

I DARE you to find a song from a modern video game done with that level of skill.

snippet.textDisplay: It's one of the best.
snippet.textOriginal: It's one of the best.

snippet.textDisplay: this metroid looks horrible
snippet.textOriginal: this metroid looks horrible

snippet.textDisplay:
Brave?  Iono, she strikes me more as the fearless type.  You heard her voice in SSBB?  She sounds cold as ice.

And yeah, she is rather dangerous, with her one-woman army approach to battle.  That and her Power Suit.
snippet.textOriginal:
Brave?  Iono, she strikes me more as the fearless type.  You heard her voice in SSBB?  She sounds cold as ice.

And yeah, she is rather dangerous, with her one-woman army approach to battle.  That and her Power Suit.

Good choice. ^-^

snippet.textDisplay: I'm a massive Metroid fan and this is probably my favourite track from the whole series, second only perhaps to the original Brinstar theme. Fantastic mood created form such a simple console, very dark and brooding. TOp stuff :)
snippet.textOriginal: I'm a massive Metroid fan and this is probably my favourite track from the whole series, second only perhaps to the original Brinstar theme. Fantastic mood created form such a simple console, very dark and brooding. TOp stuff :)
